column4: can somebody explain me is the linux-image the kernel, I mean the kernel itself?
I have installed three packages of linux-image
so does that mean I have three kernels installed?
sorry if it's stupid question but I'm not sure so I'm asking...
it's quite possible
so what is kernel-image?
I've been upgrading ubuntu so I got new kernel
it's the kernel
so the kernel image is the very kernel itself... and what about other things?
older versions of the kernel aren't removed (unless you do it explicitly) to allow you to go back to an older one if the new one has problems
so what else is considered to be kernel...
where are other dirs or kernel-image is kernel and other things are not directly connected to kernel?
basically what do I get by downloading kernel sources for example.. if you could put it that way please ...
kernel sources are needed if you are going to be compiling custom modules etc
but are kernel modules strictly related to kernel version or they're independent and kernel-image is what the very kernel is all about?
I was googling about this stuff and as far as I understud it's that way... kernel-image is the kernel and modules are used with kernel...
that's correct
so, now when I'm sure that this latest kernel works it's okay to remove kernel-images I supose, is there anything else I shoud remove or other things are not kernel specific version related?
use synaptic to remove old images, don't just delete the files
yes I ment through synaptic, but that's all I need to remove, there are no other specific kernel version related things?
I just want to learn about this stuff since I haven't studied it before :)
sorry for bothering you, but I didn't really understand this stuff so I didn't want to mess up the system...
thanks very much for explaining this to me.. I think I got it now :)
sure, no problem
